body.p:
Haveing for the first time seen
the Publication of the Occident which was lent to me
by your subscriber G. A. Hart of Greenwood Valley,
my particular attention was drawn to No 11 of
Vol. 10 Page 575 of February 1853, wherein you call
the attention of the Isrealites of this State to ende-
-avour to send a messenger to our Chinese Bresheim
in the north of China, it is a scource of pleasure that
such has come to my attention knowledge as I am able to
answer that call & perhaps Better than any other
person. I have lived in China six years out of which, four
years at Shanghai and have spoken to one of the
China Jews who was Introduced to me by a
* China merchant whoes name is Chin-Ling
Resideing within the City walls of Shanghai, but
this Jew finding that I did not know Ther? Cher-
-ter Hebrew he pronounced me unclean and said
how can a Jew travel away from his native
home without knowing it, he refused haveing
any conversation with me inconsequence of not
knowing how to kill, I was verry ancious to obtain
from him Information respecting the Jews and
after showing him my Hebrew
and explaining them to him, he said that he

was satisfied that I was a Jew, he give me a Invitation
to come out to see him, if I recollect aright
the place is called Kai-fong-fou but, I am not
positive as I have lost the Journal of my
Travels in one of the great fires in San Francisco,
the Town is situated about 900 or 1000 miles inland
from wher, I lived in Shanghai but think it lays
near the yellow River, I was ancious to go out to
his place and applied to my consul for a pass-
-port, as it was not allowed for any British or
American subject to absent himself for more
than 24 hours away from the port it being
considerd unsafte, the consul refused me
the passport stateting that it was contrary
to our Treaty for any foreingor to Travel inland.
Mr Samuel L Shuck, who his at the head of what
his termed the seventh day Babtists Mission
was verry ancious for me to go out as he said
he would like to be the first in the field to report
the mission in the United States, I, then spoke
to the Revr Dr Medhurst who was one of the
first English Missionarys to Shanghai, long
before the Americans, he could afford me no
Information excepting that it was dangerous
to travel that distance, Mr. Shuck spoke to me
again as allso the Revd Bishop Boom of the American
Church or Mission I told them that I was
ancious to start out if they could secure a
premit from the Tau-Til who is the China
Govenor of the City at Shanghai, I discoverd
afterwards that neither of the Americans would

have gone with me. I was positive that a permit
was to be procured from the Chinese Govenor by
given him a fee and paying him the expence of
the men which he sends with to protect you
which would only have been a trifle. I had
not sufficent Influence out their, being
only a Second Class Merchant, but still
think the object his to be accomplished with
-out so much danger as has been represented
to me, I have studied the habits and customs of the
People which is most esential to gain their favour and
by so doing the english authorites has more Influence
with the Chinese than the americans, the disguse for
a missionary to travel in must be the Chinese costume,
your hair shaved close up to the crown with a long
tail part of the eyebrows shave as allso face,
the winter months are November when it rains
in Torrents, December, January, February it snows, March
Strong wind & rain, April is the spring of the year
May, June July. August hot weather in the cold
weather the Chinese wear a cover over their heads
which partly conceals their face, I have been
full seventy miles in Land without any pass
was away three clear days in plain dress
(no disguise) I found the people very hospitable
and quiet it was on a sporting tour. Could
I have procured a guid and if any of my guests
would have gone with me I would have
gone further to endeavourd to accomplished
my wish, of traceing out some of my Bretherin
the one who spoke to me understands Hebrew

and told me his name which I was particular in
writing down in my Journal as allso the name of
the street in which he lived he said there was about
2000 Jews liveing in one district, and about 100 miles
further there was as many more, the men whome
you may send out as missionarys aught to know
how to speak french or Portegues you will find
it a great acquisition as the Catholics have taught
several of the Chines and then they are made
priests, furthermore, they must be good Hebrew
Schollars of good Temper and of strong
constitution as while on their Travels they aught
to live like the Chinese, I was the first
foreign Jew that went to reside at Shanghai,
Mr Lewis who is now dead was the second
he represented the firm of Philips Moore & Co
of Birmingham in England, that firm has
no establishment in Shanghai since / 49 but
they keep up their House in HongKong, Mr Aroone
was the third he arrived from Hambourg he was a man
greatly disliked by the mercantile community for his
low trickery in Business, the fourth was a Mr Isaac
Reubin a Babeylon Jew, the latter place is known
in the present days as Bagdad in the east Indias, the
head of that firm resides at Bombay the firm is
well known their & in China as Sassoon, Sons, & Co.
Elisia & David resides at Canton and Reubin represents
the firm at Shanghai they are verry wealthy and
as ? Jews as I ever see or heard of in June 1849

I left China & came to this country eighteen months
previous of my leaveing I written a letter to London about
the China Jews and I think it was the late Cheif
Rabbi Dr. Solomon Hershial said that if some
Religious Jew in China would write to him con-
-cerning the China Jews he would be happy to
corrospond with him as then he could have
more confidence, Mr Lesser I was not religious
I could not be I did not know how to kill
and when Mr Isaac Reubin came up he was
going to teach me, in /49 at San Francisco I became
acquainted with Myer Reifiseh who arrived here
from the atlantic states he toled me that he see
my Letter laying on the Table at the Cheif Rabbis
House in London they would not corrospond
with me because I was what is termed link or
(not frume) here, I must praise myself by stateing
that I had a good heart and attended to my fellow
Creatures when they was attacked with fevers which
was contagious, so that they should not die for the
want of assistance to which I wher on my finger
to this moment a Token of Regard and hold Letters
of thanks from the British authorietes in China,
out of eighty four who was resideing in Hong Kong
in them days only thirty eight survied in six weeks & some left
the place I was one that did not leave, what to
leave a place when I had convinceing proofs of
my fellow creatures dying for the want of attendance
no man that has the feeling of a Jew could do
that. in this county in December 49 I was one of the five
who proposed & collected subscription for a Jews

Burial Ground in 1850 when the two congregations was
endeavouring to join but could not agree a few
english & american went togather and formed a
Temporary Synagogue which was Burnt in/51
we reassembled and Mr J Joseph an American of
South Caroline was elected our Parness and join,
corrospondent S. H. Cohen was elected secritary out
38 Votes I had 36 they proposed to Give me a Salary
but I strongly protested against any such propo-
-sition as it was only out of pure Love for my
Religion that I accepted the office, during the time
I held that office I transacted no Business on
our Sabbath day, in the following year I resigned
as Business called me to the interior, the committee
of the congregation Shearith Isreal which was
the name of it slated a Letter of thanks for my
services. but I am Deviating from what
I commenced on therefore beg to be excused,
I must now bring this letter to a close as
I am continuely being disturbed. I wish to impress
on your mind that you must not belive
one half you hear or read of our American
missionarys in China, the Public in the states are
not aware of the gross Impocistions that is being
practised on them by these men and more
particular by this said Saml. L Shuck who is at
the head of the seventh day Babtists in Shanghai
these men did not live a stones throw from me
these missionarys encount no danger as they doo
not go out but Live in all the Luxury that the

Greatis? Merchants live in, when were they go out its
not more than 8 or 10 miles from their homes. They
convert the Chinese, and then send them out,
I could unfold the whole of their Trickery and
in one instance, Shucks Base & corrupt conduct
but the people in the states could not belive it,
but the old residense of China has seen it they
receive from the mission in the states from
$800 to 1500$ per year Salary and house rent found
them, in 1845 when I went to reside at Shange there
was a Macoa Schooner arrived there, with five
Italian Jesuite Missionarys they wher entire
strangers they and went in the country, in/46 five more
arrived in/47 five more and up to May/49 these
fifteen had converted upwards of 40,000 Chinese,
to their Religeon Old Pardre Buffo toled me
that they had converted upwards of 60 000 the greater
portion of these converts reside on the other side of the
Shanghai river they had five places of worship eight
miles distant from each other a Mr Burton an
American from Boston Mr Carvello of Macoa and
myself went over and proceeded full Twenty five
miles inland in our Plain citizens dress and with
out any passport, and a more quiet Peaceful
Peaceable & Hospitable race of men I never meet
with in all my travels which, I have been on, for
fourteen years this month. when I left Shanghai
the Italian missionary was haveing Built a
Large Colledge fronting the Shanghai River
200 feet long by this time it must have been

compleated, this is situated six miles from wher our
shipping lays six miles still further up the river his
the Chinese Pagoda a place that almost every
stranger visites but they are not aware that there
his a large mission House and the Italian
missionarys teach the Chinese to sculpher
Portrate Painting and all kinds of traides. when
I commenced this letter I little thought it would
be so long but find the more I write the more
I can think of no doubt your patients are almost
tierd out, therefore shall leave you to publish
to the world what part you may deem proper
and shall subscribe my self yours

if you have any desire to know my connections by applying
to the Revr Saml. Isaacs of New York or the Revd Moses N
Nathan of New Orleans the latter Gent his a first cousin
of mine and my first Hebrew Teacher I am allso a
nephew to Moses Eliazer Solomons Hebrew
of London and the only english Jew that ever wore
his Beard, any communication that you may
have with me please direct to care of B. Keesing Post
office Box 488 San Francisco

note * by the discription he give me of the synagogue,
it is like the one in Bevers Marks London
